Experiments are specified via the microC main web page (Figure 1). The user may set a number of numerical parameters via sliders, specify the gene network, mutations, and parameters that control diffusion (please, refer to the microC-detailed-protocol.pdf for more details). microC modules are enabled through the specification files. For example setting parameters for Oxygen or any output node within diffusion-parameters.txt, will automatically enable a diffusion module for this substance. The "Run expreriment" buttom submits the expreriment to the computing cluster.

Upon submission of the experiment (“Run Experiment” button, Figure 1) the user receives a link (Figure 2) that provides information about the status of the submission and the log file, where potential errrors are shown. Once the experiment has finished the same link will contain the results (that gradually become available in batches 16 replicates). Optionally, the user will be notified by email.

The results page displays data across all replicates and permits the viewer to inspect any of the replicates in detail. An animation of all replicates is displayed in the initial page along with averaged and detailed data for each of the experimental replicate (Figure 3). A more detailed presentation of the results page is available in the documation page of microc (http://microc.org), or microC-detailed-protocol.pdf .

description:
microC is a multiscale virtual microenvironment for perturbation biology. It enables experiments that link genotype to phenotype taking into account the surrounding microenvironment. microC has a modular architecture that enables a wide variety of experiment. Furthermore, it offers easy access to advanced computational modelling and supercomputing resources to the wider scientific community.
microC combines agent-based and gene network modelling and uses partial differential equations to simulate interactions among cells.
The tool itself does not require any installation on the user’s machine, as it can be accessed using a web browser. Experimental results and data are also available via a web interface. This protocol describes the process of preparing and submiting an experiment with microC, and interpreting the simulation results
